Quite reluctant at first, I let myself get drawn in. Here we follow a hitman who is supposed to be cold and amoral and, of course, always successful. Except that one day he misses his target, and that's when the trouble starts. He is attacked and has to track down the shooter and the person who hired him. 
The beginning made me smile with its cold tones and cold wave music, good nihilism where nothing matters, nothing makes sense, desaturated colors, like season 1 of True Detective, but without the atmosphere. 
Some people like it, but I'm not so sure. 
I had this unpleasant feeling of a mix between Nic Pizzolatto's series and the movie Fight Club, no doubt David Fincher's influence. The second tropical part is nice, but nothing more. 
So yes, it's beautiful, it's smooth, it's cold, but it's a revenge movie like Taken, only much better. 
What bothered me was the rather facile criticism of the luxurious lifestyle of the powerful, with its ultra-stylish, rootless elements, large empty houses, and technological gadgets. On the other hand, there is noise and dirt. It's probably quite realistic, but other films have already dealt with this postmodern emptiness, and perhaps better. 
Enjoyable to watch, but rather pointless, just like the vision of luxury and power that it denounces.

Driven by electric performances and pulse-pounding paranoia, The Killer's smartly rendered characters are only slightly offset by its repetitive plotting, resulting in a thriller that, while not peak Fincher, is an assured testament to his refined visual approach and pitch-perfect sound design.
In a similar vein as SE7EN. Slow & methodical but lots of suspense & surprises throughout. The ending was a bit unfulfilling - but worth a watch.

David Fincher con un'interessante rivisitazione della figura del killer, spietato e calcolatore ma allo stesso tempo quasi ironico nel suo voler controllare tutto senza nessuna possibilità di riuscirci.
Michael Fassbender viene disinnescato del suo fascino per rendere il suo protagonista apatico e freddo nel suo lavoro, seppure l'accenno di vita personale mostra una faccia completamente diversa.
La vera, seppure limitata verità, è quella di mostrare finalmente un killer convinto del suo lavoro e non, come troppo spesso accade, un personaggio pentito o sull'orlo della pensione; questo permette di vedere all'opera un un uomo che crede nel suo "lavoro" sebbene la trama prenda la stessa piega degli altri film del genere, perdendosi in una serie di combattimenti ed omicidi dove l'unica cosa che continua a sorprendere è la freddezza e la spietatezza del suo protagonista.
Interessante la voce narrante del protagonista che fornisce una realtà soggettiva del racconto ma che punta a renderlo più filosofico che di azione.

Michael Fassbender (supported by an excellent cast, script & direction) plays a dedicated professional hitman. Prepare to fully immerse yourself in a fully believable character and prepare for the unexpected. If you enjoy physiological thrillers you will love the in depth thought process, rising tension and thought provoking script. True class.

Clean, delicate, refined — with a distinct sense of style.

In the first twenty minutes, David Fincher uses the protagonist’s inner monologue to build a complete worldview, life philosophy, and value system for those who try to find their place in the world through professionalism.

The remaining hour and a half is a quiet revelation: no matter how meticulous or precise you are, relying on your profession alone can’t guarantee perfection. Because at the end of the day, you're still human — not a god.

And if you fail, that’s okay.

No matter how irreversible the outcome, no matter how heavy the consequences, all you need to do is breathe and stay calm.

Keep your reason. Make a plan — and execute it. Through execution, set things right again.

Finchers style is heavy in this movie, which does have some good parts. I found the opening sequence where the main character says "if you can't handle boredom" you're not going to make it in this business, to be prophetic for the rest of the movie. 

There is plenty going on in the film, but you never quite feel attached to any character. The protagonists girlfriend is treated purely as a plot point to motivate the assassin. Her brother is the worst actor in the film and is supposed to help up the stakes, but the whole hospital scene falls flat and doesn't feel like enough.

He spends most of the film monologuing about his own rules and how they don't permit mercy or empathy only for the main antagonist to receive mercy. The character and this movie is filled with contradictions that don't feel on-purpose.  Lots of talking about how competent the main character is, but not much showing. The opening sequence he's hiding in a dark room away from a window, but has a spotlight on him. No one notices him. 

I ended the film feeling badly for 3/4 people he killed and disliking the assassin.
